Amul has evolved from a dairy to a nutrition brand and is probably the most underrated case study in modern day business. They did a revenue of 90,000cr in FY25. Hard to think of another company in the world that has done something similar. Notes on what i think they got right..

1) They innovate at cooperative speed not startup speed and still wins. Launched 250 product launches in 5 years and that's crazy speed for a cooperative with millions of farmers, 18000+ village societies, and government-linked processes. Most companies will shiver at this speed.

2) They turned cold chain into a moat decades before most startups spoke about supply chain tech. They run India‚Äôs largest cold supply chain with refrigeration networks across rural area and temperature controlled logistics in small towns. This single capability lets them enter any nutrition category quickly.

3) The nutrition transition feels like farmer driven. More milk production means surplus fat & SNF (casien, whey , lactose) and therefore opportunity to create value added products. Every new category like whey, chocolates, drinks, cheese, creates more value for farmers. Most nutrition brands optimise for margins but they optimise for farmer income.

4) Amul is probably the only brand that simultaneously sells mass and premium products all under same brand,  same dairy and distribution and with same trust. Their products range for Rs 5 to 500. Most brands split into sub brands while Amul let the trust carry everything.

No obsession with burn, CAC ,CM1/2 growth and branding. They quietly proved that trust, scale and farmer first thinking can still beat everyone.

America just put a $100,000 price tag on the Indian dream. Never been a better time than now for Indian engineers to build at home. The US was the promised land for Indian engineers but not anymore. And India isn‚Äôt the India of the 90s when engineers moved out for better pay and exposure. 

Earlier generations left India because they didn‚Äôt have a choice. Today, staying back is the smarter choice. The US is telling the world that they want fewer immigrants, at higher prices & under tighter conditions. 

In the 1960s & 70s, US actively recruited Indian doctors and engineers to fill shortages. In the 90s & 2000s, IT/software outsourcing made H-1B the obvious path for thousands of engineers. In reality, the India of today is not the India many left behind. 

This is not to say India is without its own constraints. We still have infrastructure gaps and bureaucracy is still frustrating.
But if you look back at history, Indian engineers have always thrived precisely in moments of constraint. 

The outsourcing opportunity of the 90s was born from wage arbitrage. The SaaS opportunity of the 2010s came from building global software with frugal & distributed teams. Each cycle has taken adversity and Indian entrepreneurs turned it into advantage.

The next cycle will be no different. The very inefficiencies of India around fragmented supply chains, healthcare gaps, broken education models will be the anchor to build world class companies. To solve for India is to solve for the future of other emerging markets.

This is the great inversion of our time and for the first time in history, the opportunity cost of leaving India may be greater than the opportunity cost of staying.

The last generation of Indian engineers built America‚Äôs tech backbone. The next generation has the chance to build India‚Äôs. Come back home. Time to build for India and from India.

text:
Every week, I get a 10 new startup pitches that says ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll deliver healthcare in 10 minutes.‚Äù Quick commerce is now rushing into healthcare. So I thought to do a breakdown on what‚Äôs hype and what might actually work in India. 

What could work?
1)30‚Äì60 min medicine delivery can work for chronic refills or acute needs. In metros with dense demand, it's useful. But 10-min isn‚Äôt necessary. Even same-day is fine for 90% of use cases. And honestly, your local chemist is already doing that.

2) Rapid diagnostics for home blood collection isn‚Äôt about speed but it‚Äôs about hygiene and reliability. A 2-hour sample pickup and next-morning results is a solid win. What we need is better logistics and trained phlebotomists, not faster scooters.

3)On-demand nursing or paramedic visits but for use cases like wound care, IV, injections. Could work with proper scheduling. Think ‚ÄúOla for nurses,‚Äù not ‚ÄúBlinkit for bandages.‚Äù Needs backend infra for verification, training, EMR integration.

What won‚Äôt work (At least not now)
1) Ambulance in 10 mins sounds great until you hit Delhi or Bangalore traffic. Speed is useless without triage and location accuracy. What we really need is better coordination between hospitals and ambulance providers, not just faster wheels.

2) On-demand doctors in 10 mins is a bad idea. You don‚Äôt need any doctor fast but you need the right one. Discovery & matching are bigger problems than speed. Most video consults struggle with quality, not timing. Clinical care isn‚Äôt fast food. Trust takes time.

3) The 10-min everything app for healthcare is lazy ambition dressed up with VC money. Healthcare isn‚Äôt a SKU game but it‚Äôs complex, regulated, and hard to standardize like groceries. Great for funding buzz, terrible for trust and real outcomes.

Few thoughts if you really are passionate to build in healthcare. 
Trust > velocity.
Speed isn‚Äôt everything.
Infra & people ops > APIs.
Reliability > 10-min hacks.
Health is longitudinal & not transactional.

Good luck if you're building something in Healthcare in India.

Doctors in India die earlier than their patients. I know it sounds crude but what it means is Indian doctors have a life expectancy that‚Äôs nearly 10 years shorter than the average Indian. And this is reported by Indian Medical Association. 

The primary causes are Cardiovascular disease and infections. Ironically, the very things they work tirelessly to prevent.

Endure 10-12 years of medical education with the only aspiration to save lives but be at the receiving end of stress, anxiety, and long working hours. And be a part of a system that doesn‚Äôt give them time to care for their own health. The average Indian doctor clocks 60‚Äì80 hours a week and approx 300-400 doctors die by suicide every year. Mostly because of the impossible expectations they carry. It takes 10+ years of study before a doctor sees their first salary.

They‚Äôre taught that saving lives is everything. After 10hrs+ of work, you can then go and figure your own personal health & family life. And after all this, they‚Äôre now told that AI will make them obsolete. That their jobs will be replaced by software tools because the system is inefficient.

I meet atleast 50 companies a month that pitch AI solutions for healthcare. These tools matter and they can make processes faster and improve accessibility. No doubt Indian healthcare needs better processes and better tech. But what it needs more than anything is empathy.

India‚Äôs hospitals are crowded and the health crisis is real. But what‚Äôs also been ignored is the mental and physical health of our doctors & medical staff. 

This isn‚Äôt a rant against technology, AI or healthcare system. But a reminder to self and maybe a few who are reading this that without empathy and without recognizing the human cost, there will be no healthcare system left.

Big fan of what Y Combinator has done for founders. But I‚Äôve never understood the obsession with building a YC equivalent in India by investors here. I‚Äôm convinced it will never happen. Not because we lack talent or ambition, but because YC wasn‚Äôt just a structure. It was the outcome of a rare mix of time, place, and cultural defaults.

YC emerged in a place where risk was cheap, talent was abundant, trust was a default & failure was celebrated as a credential. India has almost none of those ingredients in the same proportion yet.

Indian founders are world class at surviving, hacking & stretching resources. But YC worked because it taught founders to focus on scaling instead of surviving.
Indian early stage capital still acts like it's lending money , not taking risk. Even seed rounds come with board seats and monthly reporting. 

The genius of YC was its narrative monopoly. They created status & not just capital. India‚Äôs status economy works differently. You can‚Äôt manufacture prestige in India without a IIT, IIM next to your name.

India won‚Äôt have its YC. But maybe that‚Äôs a good thing. 
What we need in India is founder first micro VCs with real skin in the game. A media and narrative engine that spotlights Indian builders solving Indian and world problems from India.

text:
Because we invest in healthcare, I get this question all the time: Will AI replace doctors? As a technology optimist I don‚Äôt claim to have all the answers. But i feel this question usually reveals how little we understand both about AI & healthcare.

When people say AI will replace doctors and teachers in the next decade. They  assume that intelligence is enough to make an impact and forgets that trust is the real currency in both healthcare and education.

Doctors don‚Äôt just prescribe, they hold your hand during a cancer diagnosis. Teachers don‚Äôt just deliver content but they spot the kid falling behind, build confidence, and unlock potential. AI can assist, but it can‚Äôt replace human empathy and trust.

So is AI important? Absolutely.
AI can read scans better than most radiologists. It can solve for homework & personalise lessons faster than a teacher. It can democratize access to world class knowledge, in any language, at near zero cost.

But can it replace the human relationship that sits at the core of these professions? AI doesn‚Äôt replace doctors. It replaces inefficiencies around them. Likewise AI won‚Äôt replace teachers. But it can free them from admin so they can actually teach

Tech is best when it‚Äôs invisible. When it supports human work & not erase it.
Yes, AI will change healthcare & education. The goal of AI shouldn't be to replace doctors & teachers. It‚Äôs to make a billion people feel like they finally have one. That‚Äôs the real opportunity & that‚Äôs where the best builders will focus i feel.

text:
Everyone today loves this grand narrative that "Tech will fix everything". Every week a news article or investor confidently declares that tech will fix healthcare & most entrepreneurs fall for this illusion of disruption. This narrative is doing more harm than good.

Most entrepreneurs today think, if we can build a beautifully designed app, use AI to chat, automate doctor-patient interactions, and scale it to millions of users, we can "solve" healthcare. 

It sounds great in a pitch deck. It almost never works in reality.

Why? Because healthcare isn't e-commerce. You can‚Äôt scale a hospital bed like a food delivery fleet. You can‚Äôt disrupt chronic disease with a better UI. You can‚Äôt solve trust with a chatbot. Healthcare isn‚Äôt a transaction, it‚Äôs a relationship.

If you're serious about fixing healthcare, start thinking from first principles.

Everyone wants to build the ‚ÄúUber of Healthcare.‚Äù But Uber works because a ride from point A to B is a simple transaction. Healthcare isn‚Äôt. You can‚Äôt just match a patient with a doctor and assume the job is done. Don't build a generic doctor consultation app with a new UI or a marketplace that lists thousand doctor names. Focus on depth of care, outcomes, and follow-up treatments before chasing millions of users. Build a connected system that only focuses on driving outcomes.

Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics. AI can help a doctor diagnose faster. But it can‚Äôt replace the doctor. Yet, doctors alone won‚Äôt solve India‚Äôs healthcare crisis. They also need trained frontline workers assisted by smart tech. Build AI tools to assist doctors enable faster diagnoses. Don't oversell your AI engine or LLM models to a patient. 

It doesn‚Äôt matter if we have the best doctor or AI engine if the right medicine isn‚Äôt available. Up to 20% of medicines sold in India are fake or substandard. Counterfeit drugs are a massive problem & the Pharma companies are growing this $58 billion market. Perhaps a great usecase to use AI and tech to streamline the supply chain. 

So, can tech fix healthcare? Yes. 
But not by replacing doctors, hospitals, or traditional care systems. The biggest healthcare opportunities in India are not about disruption but augmentation.

Tech alone won‚Äôt fix Indian healthcare. But finding the right places to apply can make a 10x difference. Healthcare isn‚Äôt an industry that gets "disrupted" overnight. But it can be upgraded piece by piece, solving for what really matters. And if you understand that, you‚Äôll build something that actually works.

text:
Gopi is right. The reality is brutal‚Äîless than 1% of aspiring athletes make it big, and even those who do are left with little security once their careers are over. Sports, like startups, have a power law distribution‚Äî10% of players make 90% of the money. Everyone else is a statistic.

We love to read and watch the underdog story‚Äîthe kid from nowhere who makes it to the top. But that‚Äôs survivorship bias. For every one success, there are tens of thousands who trained just as hard but got nothing. The real question is: why does sports have to be a gamble?

 If you‚Äôre not in the top 1%, you don‚Äôt get sponsorships, you don‚Äôt have financial security, and once your career ends‚Äîusually in your late 20‚Äôs or early 30s‚Äîyou‚Äôre left scrambling for what‚Äôs next.

In developed nations, sports is a structured industry. There are leagues, second-tier careers, college scholarships, and post-career pathways. 

If you don‚Äôt become an Olympic champion, you can still earn a living as a coach, analyst, trainer, or minor league player. The system doesn‚Äôt discard you the moment you‚Äôre not in the top 1%.

The problem isn‚Äôt that sports is hard‚Äîit‚Äôs that failure is absolute. An engineer who fails at a startup can get a job. A failed athlete? They often have nothing. That‚Äôs why in most countries without strong sports ecosystems, success in sports correlates with wealth. You can‚Äôt afford to be an athlete unless you can afford to lose.

Right now, telling a poor kid to pursue sports is like telling them to buy lottery tickets as an investment strategy. Until we change that, Gopi‚Äôs words will remain true. And that‚Äôs a failure‚Äînot of the athletes, but of the system.

A great sports system doesn‚Äôt just create champions‚Äîit creates a nation of resilient, disciplined, and competitive people. And that‚Äôs the foundation of real development.

Building a business in preventive health is hard. No one tells you this upfront. I learned it the hard way, first as a founder, now as an investor.

You‚Äôve chosen the harder game. Not because prevention doesn‚Äôt work, but because people don‚Äôt pay for it. Most wake up thinking about chai, parathas , deadlines, and school fees. Not long-term health. People today want instant gratification‚Äîsugar today, gym tomorrow.

Curative health makes money because illness is urgent. No one postpones a bypass surgery or negotiates an ICU bill. But prevention?¬†Everyone hunts for gym discounts, coupon codes for healthy food and thinks twice before paying for a fitness program.

Hospitals & pharma companies thrive because they sell relief from suffering. And suffering is a guaranteed market‚Äîprevention is not.

That‚Äôs why venture money chases curative health‚Äîit scales fast with clear unit economics, solving problems people can‚Äôt ignore. Asking someone to eat better, sleep more, and exercise for a payoff 5‚Äì10 years later is like selling an FD over a lottery ticket. So accept this reality and build accordingly.

Yet, prevention is the hardest problem and the biggest untaped opportunity.
#1 Healthcare in India will shift to prevention-not because people suddenly care, but because not caring is becoming too expensive. 

#2 Your market isn‚Äôt TAM, it‚Äôs WTM (willing-to-pay market). Everyone should care about health, but few will pay for it.To go mass-market, make it cheaper than chai and as seamless as WhatsApp.

#3 If you‚Äôre selling prevention, reposition it. People don‚Äôt buy prevention. They buy status, performance, and convenience. Make it aspirational & competitive.

#4 Trust in health isn‚Äôt built overnight. People won‚Äôt change their habits because you raised venture money. You‚Äôre in the business of delayed gratification. That means slow &sustainable growth.

#5 If your product doesn‚Äôt make people healthier or keep them engaged long-term, the number of app downloads doesn't matter. Focus on retention, real outcomes and revenue‚Äînot GMV, DAUs or metrics to make a pitch deck look good. 

If you can do this, you won‚Äôt just build a business‚Äîyou‚Äôll change how India thinks about health. And that‚Äôs worth building for.

author.headline: Entrepreneur| Investments at Rainmatter | Endurance athlete
text:
Have met over 600+ healthcare startups this year at Rainmatter. These are my general observations of the sector in 2024 so far. An investor & health enthusiast perspective. 

Remember, these are observations and not opinions.  If you‚Äôre a builder, I'm always keen to exchange notes.

1) Health tech needs maturing ‚Äì The novelty phase of tech meets health is over and the focus should be on driving outcomes to the user.

2) Preventive health is gaining traction ‚Äì More startups are focused on preventive solutions.

3) Nutrition personalisation is heating up ‚Äì Companies are going beyond generic consulting and leveraging DNA, microbiome, or other personal data for nutrition recommendations.

4) UPI for health not yet in India- ABDM use cases haven't seen much adoption.

5) Wearables are no longer the star ‚Äì Smartwatches and rings are still strong but are considered table stakes. Consumers want something that tells ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and not limited to ‚Äúwhat‚Äù.

6) Corporate wellness is an overrated market ‚Äì With rising mental health issues, stress, and burnout in the workforce, B2B wellness solutions ideally should show promise. But there isn‚Äôt adoption from corporates.

7) The ‚Äúbiohacking‚Äù trend is niche but growing ‚Äìlongevity startups are speculative but hot.  Increasing interest in biohacking protocols (sleep optimization, anti ageing etc.). But the market is niche and often hard to validate scientifically unless clinical protocols are done.

8) Consumer trust in health supplements is dwindling ‚Äì The supplement industry lacks regulation and transparency and this has eroded trust amongst consumers. Brands are focusing on science-backed products.

9) AI in healthcare ‚Äì Many are bullish on AI‚Äôs potential to revolutionise diagnostics, patient care, and drug discovery, but deployment in clinical settings is slow and capital-intensive.

10) Mental health is booming ‚Äì Digital mental health startups, especially those offering therapy, coaching, or CBT solutions are seeing adoptions but differentiation is becoming a challenge in a crowded market.

11) Community-driven fitness ‚Äì Social, community-oriented fitness solutions still have potential if done right especially those blending real-world interactions with digital offerings.

12) CAC is a challenge for D2C health brands ‚Äì Brands are facing rising customer acquisition costs often with no sustainable GTM.

13) Hybrid health businesses are scaling better ‚Äì Companies combining digital and physical services have better scope of scaling fast.

14) Telehealth plateaued ‚Äì The initial excitement around telehealth has subsided for both consumers and investors.

15) Health marketplaces have no moat ‚Äì Platforms connecting consumers with healthcare providers or wellness services are overrated with no clear moat to grow.

author.headline: Entrepreneur| Investments at Rainmatter | Endurance athlete
text:
An unpopular opinion about founders/VC's building and investing in health category. This may disappoint a few.

First, if you are a founder building in the health. You've to walk the talk. 
What does that mean? You have to be healthy and fit. 

-The biggest moat in the health industry is trust. This can't be built by performance marketing or hiring influencers. 
-Why will a customer trust your product if the founder isn't healthy? You don't need six packs. But you shouldn't look unfit.
-If your product came out from your own problem statement, great. Tell the world how you got there and share your experience. 
-In health industry you scale by not selling features. But by earning the trust. 

Second, don't pitch or raise money from an investor who doesn't walk the talk. 

-To build a scalable business TAM is important. But impact is most important.
- If the first question they ask is, how large is the business and not why you choose to build the product. That's a sign.
- If an investor doesn't make an effort to experience your product or service and offer genuine feedback. They are truly not investing in you. But chasing vanity.
- Have seen many VC events ending with alcohol and the food corner filled with junk. And that happens because they don't walk the talk and perhaps staying healthy is not their top priority in personal life. 

That's it. Hope this changes. And we build businesses and products that brings impact on people. And trust is your anchor to scale.
